image.altText: A sign on the front of a building saying 'Genius Childcare', photographed through bars.

props.synopsis: More than a dozen staff at Genius Childcare centres in the ACT have resigned while others have taken stress leave amid allegations of ongoing pay delays.

title.children: Mass resignations at national childcare chain over allegations staff aren't being paid on time

image.altText: A man with grey hair in a navy suit looks serious.

props.synopsis: University of Canberra interim vice-chancellor Stephen Parker, who was brought on in September to prepare a 2025 budget addressing the university's difficult financial position, has resigned from the role.

title.children: University of Canberra vice-chancellor resigns, citing 'lost confidence in council'

image.altText: A woman with voluminous hair taking an image of herself in a bathroom mirror.

props.synopsis: Set against the backdrop of social change in the 1970s, Carol Jerrems's photography charted the women's movement, documented First Nations activism, put a spotlight on youth subcultures, and explored the era's music and arts scenes.

title.children: Era-defining photos of cultural icons and 'languid hangouts in share-house backyards' go on display

props.synopsis: Several teenagers were injured when a second-floor deck at a holiday rental in NSW South Coast town "gave way" during a party attended by about 40 people, according to a witness.

title.children: Teen describes screams as AirBnB balcony collapses, injuring partygoers on NSW South Coast

image.altText: A woman wearing white shirt with frilled collar speaks, in front of a window

props.synopsis: The New South Wales Health Secretary offers an apology to women who have been affected by recent abortion bans, adding that she has written to hospital executives across the state reminding them of their responsibilities.

title.children: Health secretary apologises to women unable to access abortion care after Queanbeyan and Orange hospital bans

image.altText: Underwater rugby players battle it out at the bottom of the pool

props.synopsis: Underwater rugby is a contact sport played at depths of 3.5 to 5 metres. But as old swimming complexes are redeveloped, deep pools are becoming harder to find.

title.children: This niche underwater sport faces an 'existential threat'

image.altText: A woman holding the outstretched arm of a skeleton.

props.synopsis: Multiple female physiotherapists say they've experienced gender-based harassment while working for male sporting teams, often being the only woman in the change rooms.

title.children: Female physiotherapists experiencing gender-based harassment in male-dominated industry

image.altText: A collection of fresh shucked oysters.

props.synopsis: WaterNSW has warned against eating shellfish from a large river on the New South Wales South Coast following the discovery of a potentially lethal algal bloom, raising concerns about the impact on Christmas trade for multiple oyster farmers downstream.

title.children: Swimming and eating of shellfish banned at NSW South Coast river after deadly algae warning

image.altText: A barista holding a silver milk jug  and a white cup full of coffee, pouring the milk into the coffee to make latte art

props.synopsis: A Business Council ranking of states and territories has crowned South Australia the best place in the country to run a business and labelled Victoria the worst. It could spur a debate inside Labor about whether the state is beginning to hurt Anthony Albanese's election chances.

title.children: Victoria named worst state to open new cafe as Labor debates brand damage in Albanese stronghold

image.altText: close up of stone pub called the Parkside Hotel

props.synopsis: A national company appears to walk back a reported notice to venue managers about celebrating Australia Day on January 26, saying in a statement its comments caused "concern and confusion".

title.children: Hospitality group apologises after reportedly telling pubs not to celebrate Australia Day

props.synopsis: The Australian facial injectables industry was estimated to be worth $4.1 billion in 2023, with big corporates including Wesfarmers owning a slice of the market. But the business model behind the boom has attracted complaints and raised some safety concerns.

title.children: A business model called 'scripting' has seen cosmetic injectables boom, but it's not without risk

image.altText: A man and a woman smile at the camera. They are holding a small girl.

props.synopsis: Meatworkers Jordan Cullinane, 23, and Remi Krahenbring, 25, knew they didn't want to be paying off someone else's mortgage, so they put their heads down and started saving.

title.children: 'We saved for this': Young couple crack housing dream

image.altText: a kayaker on the water at dawn at Toronto Lake Macquarie NSW

props.synopsis: Another heatwave is predicted across Australia this week, as the weather bureau confirms the nation just sizzled through its hottest spring on record.

title.children: Australia sweats through hottest spring on record as temperatures soar 2.5C above pre-industrial levels

image.altText: A view from behind of military graduates in full dress uniform, marching.

props.synopsis: Legislative changes will be enacted to establish a new oversight body as the government accepts several proposals including mandatory discharge for sexual offences.

title.children: ADF members to be discharged for sexual offences as government implements most royal commission recommendations

image.altText: Man wearing a suit with a red tie.

props.synopsis: A Liberal National Party MP has told federal parliament "you cannot possibly compare" women who work in childcare with men who work in construction during a debate about gender pay equity.

title.children: 'Many women don't want to be CEOs': Coalition MP criticised over gender pay gap comments

image.altText: Two men and a child walk down a street

props.synopsis: Joe Biden just broke a vow to never pardon his son. Here's why he changed his mind and how the act of clemency will impact his son and Joe Biden's political legacy.

title.children: Presidents often grant 'midnight pardons' on their final day in power. Here's why Biden wouldn't wait

image.altText: Lando Norris has wine poured on him by Charles Leclerc and Max Verstappen on the F1 podium.

props.synopsis: F1 has had a drivers' and constructors' championships for the past 67 years and they usually go to the same team, but there are exceptions.

title.children: F1 has two world championships and just like 2024, they do not always go to the same team

image.altText: Image of Venus's clouds taken by the Akatsuki spacecraft.

props.synopsis: Venus was once covered in water. Or was it? An analysis of our twin planet’s atmosphere suggests it could never have supported life.

title.children: Scientists thought Venus was once like Earth. A new study suggests it never had water

image.altText: Donald Trump points his finger while partially poking his tongue out

props.synopsis: As the US president-elect threatens to make it costly for a group of nine developing nations to drop the US dollar as their go-to currency for international trade, we look at whether they have the capacity to actually do so.

title.children: Trump threatens BRICS nations with 100pc tariffs over currency plans

image.altText: A close up of a koala eating leaves.

props.synopsis: Researchers from the University of Sydney undertook the task in the wake of the Black Summer bushfires, when they found there was a lack of data to be able to quantify the loss to the koala population.

title.children: The '3-billion-piece puzzle' researchers hope will help save koalas from extinction

image.altText: A graphic of a speed limit for a 90kph zone.

props.synopsis: Driving in later life can bring its own challenges, and while rules around older road users vary widely across the country, options for navigating those challenges include licence assessments and conversations around so-called "driving retirement".

title.children: There are speed limits on the roads — but should there be age limits?

image.altText: A young man with short dark hair is sitting in front of a microphone wearing headphones in the ABC radio studio.

props.synopsis: Alex Whitton has a degree, volunteer experience and plenty of enthusiasm, but says employers often don't see past his disability.

title.children: Seeing the potential of jobseekers with a disability is clouded in judgement

image.altText: A large water filtration system being constructed outside one a concrete slab.

props.synopsis: The $3.5-million upgrade to the Cascade filtration plant will help make drinking water safe again for thousands of residents after PFAS was found in two dams supplying water to the plant.

title.children: Mobile treatment system installed to remove cancer-linked 'forever chemicals' from Blue Mountains drinking water

image.altText: Woman putting bread into a toaster in a small kitchen.

props.synopsis: There's pressure on the government to fund and build more social and affordable housing, with one insider describing the shortage as "extremely severe".

title.children: Rebecca is living in a hotel with five kids while they wait for social housing

image.altText: A submarine surfaces in open water

props.synopsis: The Philippine navy and air force were dispatched to monitor the submarine as it moved through the contested area.

title.children: 'Very worrisome': Philippines President alarmed by Russian submarine in South China Sea

image.altText: Rooftop solar with powerlines in background

props.synopsis: With the rise and rise of rooftop solar showing no signs of stopping in Australia, the market operator says "emergency" powers to control it are urgently needed.

title.children: Market operator says emergency powers needed to switch off panels as solar tsunami 'threatens wipeout'

image.altText: Ian Smith

props.synopsis: The 87-year-old actor reveals he has left his role as Harold Bishop on Neighbours after being diagnosed with a "very aggressive" form of cancer.

title.children: Neighbours star Ian Smith reveals terminal cancer diagnosis

image.altText: Close-up of the cocaine bricks.

props.synopsis: Police have made the largest cocaine seizure in Australian history following an investigation into a transnational organised crime syndicate accused of conspiring to import more than two tonnes of the drug into Australia.

title.children: Comanchero bikie leader charged over bungled attempt to bring 2.34 tonnes of cocaine into Australia

image.altText: People running out onto a street.

props.synopsis: The stampede broke out on Sunday afternoon at the stadium in the city of Nzerekore during the final of a local tournament.

title.children: More than 50 people killed in stampede following clashes at a Guinea soccer match

image.altText: Supreme Court WA

props.synopsis: The four people accused of murdering Perth schoolboy Cassius Turvey formally enter pleas of not guilty in WA's Supreme Court.

title.children: Four people accused of murdering Cassius Turvey plead not guilty in Supreme Court

image.altText: A large red and white passenger ferry in a body of water against a wintery backdrop

props.synopsis: The Spirit of Tasmania IV ferry is making its way across the North Sea to its temporary home in Scotland, but taxpayers are yet to learn how much it will cost to remain there.

title.children: As the newest Spirit of Tasmania ferry heads to its temporary home in Scotland, berthing costs remain unknown

image.altText: chihuahua sat in a trolley wearing a green shirt that says brat at new york dog parade

props.synopsis: Each year, a number of words rise above and define the feelings of so many people across the world, and each year the world's top dictionaries select a word as the best of the year.

title.children: From brat to enshittification and everything in between, these are the 2024 'words of the year'

image.altText: Chickens stick their heads out from cages at a farm.

props.synopsis: Australia's surveillance of bird flu has been described as a possible "model" to follow globally, with the spread of the H5N1 strain of the virus causing concerns for international health authorities.

title.children: There's only one continent without the deadly H5N1 bird flu strain. The approach might make Australia a 'world leader'

props.synopsis: As more cracks appear in the burgeoning super industry, performance won't take centre stage. The trust gap will.

title.children: New battleground starting to open up over superannuation

image.altText: spade tooth dolphin

props.synopsis: Scientists in New Zealand have begun dissecting what is considered the rarest whale in the world, a species so elusive that only seven of the animals have ever been documented.

title.children: NZ scientists dissect rare spade-toothed whale
